importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: China expanded export controls on 12 out of 17 rare-earth metals and certain refining equipment, effective December 1, as a response to US trade restrictions.
Trump announced a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective from November 1, in response to China’s rare earth export controls.
Trump and Xi are expected to meet in South Korea during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, with the trade dispute complicating the diplomatic meeting.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period saw a series of escalating US-China trade measures, including export controls on semiconductors, restrictions on Huawei, and Biden’s chip export bans, reflecting a broader strategic economic competition.
The recent escalation of tariffs and export controls, especially Trump’s 100% tariff threat and China’s rare earth restrictions, signals a resurgence of trade tensions after a 90-day truce.

keyTakeAways: The US has a history of imposing escalating tariffs on Chinese goods, starting with a 10% tariff in 2024, rising to 145% in 2024, and culminating in a 100% tariff threat by Trump in October 2025.
China responded by expanding rare earth export controls on 12 out of 17 metals and restricting refining equipment, citing US trade curbs on Chinese industries and national security concerns.
The actions are seen as a strategic pre-meeting move ahead of the expected Trump-Xi meeting in South Korea, with China aiming to gain leverage in negotiations.
Both nations have weaponized economic interdependence, using export controls and tariffs as tools of geopolitical pressure, reflecting a deeper integration of economic and security policies.
Experts note that while the US has broader global economic reach and domestic resilience, China has shown more strategic planning and flexibility through phased restrictions.
The trade war threatens global supply chains, particularly in critical technologies like semiconductors and electric vehicles, which rely on rare earth minerals.

Despite claims of mutual harm, both sides are maintaining escalation tools, suggesting a standoff where neither wants to back down, with outcomes depending on market reactions and global economic stability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details a renewed escalation of US-China trade tensions, with US President Donald Trump threatening a 100% tariff on Chinese goods in response to China’s expanded export controls on rare earth minerals. China justifies its actions as a defense of national security and a reaction to US trade restrictions targeting its industries, including maritime and shipbuilding sectors. The timing of these measures—weeks before the expected meeting between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping in South Korea—suggests strategic pre-emption. Historical context shows a pattern of tit-for-tat tariffs and export controls dating back to 2018, including Trump’s initial 25% tariffs, Biden’s semiconductor export bans, and restrictions on Huawei and TikTok. Experts argue that both nations are using economic tools as instruments of geopolitical strategy, with China showing greater strategic coordination and the US relying on market-based leverage. The conflict threatens global supply chains, especially in high-tech and defense sectors, and underscores the growing integration of economic and national security policies in great power competition. While both sides maintain escalation tools, market reactions and global economic stability will ultimately determine the outcome.
title: Trump’s 100% tariff threat: History of US trade measures against China
